CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG , reiterating her earlier complaints . In addition , relying on LAW , she complained that she had received ORG decision DATE after it had been adopted and that it had taken DATE for ORG to decide on her appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It found that the elements required under LAW of LAW to involuntarily admit the applicant to a closed institution had been established by the lower courts which in their decisions had referred to ORG opinions . As regards the DATE delay that had elapsed before ORG had heard the applicant , ORG stated as follows :

“ CARDINAL . In response to the claim in the [ present ] appeal concerning a violation of the second sentence of LAW of LAW the ORG ” ] , the [ ORG ] notes the following . In the event of the admission of a person to a closed institution pursuant to the procedure for the application of interim measures , the person himself or herself , and those close to him or her , have to be heard ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the ORG ) . The second sentence of LAW of the ORG allows for an exception from this rule to be made if the hearing may cause significant damage to the health of the person or if the person is clearly not able to express his or her will . According to the first sentence of LAW of the ORG , due to the potential danger resulting from a delay ( the meaning of the provision indicates that reference is made to danger to the person ’s own life or other ORG lives , health or safety ) , interim measures may be applied before hearing the person himself or herself and the other persons , and before appointing a representative for him or her . According to the second sentence of LAW of the ORG , such [ hearing and appointment ] must be performed promptly thereafter . The [ ORG ] considers that the main purpose of LAW ( CARDINAL ) and the second sentence of § MONEY ( CARDINAL ) of the ORG is the need to prevent an unfounded admission of a person to a closed institution or the opportunity to decide on the termination of the admission pursuant to LAW ORG .

In the present case , ORG heard the person concerned DATE after the decision to apply interim measures had been taken . The [ ORG ] finds that in the present case ORG has not given reasons for the DATE delay . Although the second sentence of LAW of the ORG obliges the court to promptly perform certain acts ( hear the person himself or herself and the other persons named in the law , and appoint him or her a representative ) , the meaning of the law is that the person concerned has to be heard in the first place . Since the person concerned , as a rule , will have been admitted to the closed institution by that time , his or her whereabouts will be known to the court . If there were any objective circumstances preventing the court from hearing the person concerned herself , or if there were any circumstances mentioned in the second sentence of LAW of the ORG ( hearing the person concerned would cause significant damage to his or her health , or he or she is clearly not able to express his or her will ) , pertinent reasons should have been set out in the decision . However , the aforementioned violation of the norms of procedure is not so important that it would result in quashing the ruling . ORG has heard the person concerned and , based on the materials in the case file and the rulings made , the courts have not had doubts as to the existence of the prerequisites for the person ’s admission to the closed institution or as to their cessation . ”
CARDINAL . LAW ( Psühhiaatrilise abi seadus ) , as in force at the material time , provided :

“ ( CARDINAL ) A person may be admitted to the psychiatric department of a hospital for emergency psychiatric care without the consent of the person or his or her legal representative , or the treatment of a person may be continued regardless of his or her wishes , only if all of the following circumstances exist :
CARDINAL . NORP the person has a severe mental disorder which restricts his or her ability to understand or control his or her behaviour ;
CARDINAL . NORP without inpatient treatment , the person may endanger the life , health or safety of himself or herself or others due to the mental disorder ; and
CARDINAL . NORP other psychiatric care is not sufficient .

( CARDINAL ) ORG treatment may be applied only on the basis of a court ’s decision . Involuntary care may be applied in the absence of a court ’s decision if this is unavoidable for the protection of the person or the public and a court ’s decision can not be obtained sufficiently promptly .

( CARDINAL ) A decision to apply involuntary treatment in the absence of a court ’s decision shall be made by a psychiatrist on the admission of the person to the psychiatric department of the hospital ... promptly after his or her medical examination . ...
( CARDINAL ) ORG treatment on the basis of a decision referred to in subsection CARDINAL may be applied for TIME from the beginning of the involuntary treatment .

“ ( CARDINAL ) A request to apply involuntary treatment and admit a person to a hospital ’s psychiatric department under the procedure for the application of interim measures shall be made to the court in the area where the hospital is located by the hospital ’s chief doctor . ... ”
CARDINAL . Admission of persons to closed institutions is dealt with in LAW of LAW ( GPE seadustik ) . As in force at the material time , it provided :

“ Pursuant to the procedure provided in this LAW , the court shall conduct proceedings concerning the following matters based on a petition by the rural municipality or city government of the residence of the person :
CARDINAL . NORP the admission of a mentally ill person to a psychiatric hospital or a social welfare institution against his or her will , together with deprivation of the liberty of the person ;
CARDINAL . NORP other matters concerning the admission of a person to a closed institution provided by law . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) Based on the request of the petitioner , the court may [ order the ] admission of a person to a closed institution pursuant to the procedure for the application of interim measures , if :
CARDINAL . NORP the conditions of admission to a closed institution are clearly met and a delay is likely to result in danger , and
CARDINAL . documents exist concerning the person ’s state of health , and
CARDINAL . a representative has been appointed for the person [ concerned ] in the proceedings , and
CARDINAL . NORP the person himself or herself , and the persons specified in LAW , have been heard .
( CARDINAL ) ... A person need not be heard if this may cause significant damage to his or her health or if the person is clearly not able to express his or her will .

( CARDINAL ) If a delay could result in danger , the court may apply interim measures even before hearing the person himself or herself and the other persons , and before appointing a representative for him or her . In such a case , such [ hearing and appointment ] must be performed promptly ( viivitamata ) thereafter .

( CARDINAL ) Interim measures may be applied for a period of DATE . After hearing an expert , such term may be extended to DATE . Such term shall also include the time the person is admitted to a closed institution for examination .

( CARDINAL ) In the cases and pursuant to the procedure provided by law , a person may be admitted to a closed institution without a court ruling if this is strictly necessary for the protection of the person himself or herself or the public , and a court ruling can not be obtained promptly enough . In such a case , a petition for obtaining a court ruling shall be submitted no later than during the following DATE . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) If it is clearly necessary in the interests of the person and the person is not represented by another person with full legal capacity [ to take part in ] civil proceedings , the court shall appoint a representative for the person [ concerned ] in proceedings for the admission of the person to a closed institution .

“ ( CARDINAL ) Before a person is admitted to a closed institution , the person must be heard in person by the court and the court shall explain the course of the proceedings to him or her . If necessary , the court shall hear the person in his or her usual environment . ...
( CARDINAL ) Before a person is admitted to a closed institution , the court shall also hear the opinion of the rural municipality or city government , and the following persons :
CARDINAL . NORP the spouse of the person , and other family members who live or have lived together with the person ;
CARDINAL . NORP the guardian or caregiver of the person ;
CARDINAL . NORP the trustee appointed by the person ;
CARDINAL . NORP the head of the closed institution in which the person has been admitted , or an official appointed thereby .

“ ( CARDINAL ) The court shall terminate the admission of a person to a closed institution by a ruling after the prerequisites thereof have ceased to exist . The court may also terminate admission to a closed institution based on an application by the person himself or herself , the petitioner or at the initiative of the court . Before terminating a person ’s admission to a closed institution , the court shall obtain the opinion of the rural municipality or city government .
